indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Total funds donated to implement development projects - Number of projects supported and implemented through the donations -Number of Lebanese expatriate organizations and individuals signed up as ‘friends of Live Lebanon’ on the website or on the Facebook Group - Number of visits to the website -Number of workshops/events arranged worldwide under the name of or in association with Live Lebanon -number of volunteers involved with the promotion of LIVE LEBANON

baseline.comment: -No nationwide, formal, neutral and apolitical structure/channel for Lebanese Diaspora to be engaged in the support of local communities in the most deprived areas of the country -Remittances are mainly given as private donations to individuals -No online system to channel remittances collectively for developmental purposes

target.comment: At least 10 community based projects are implemented At least 2 partnerships with private sector are developed At least two events are executed to ensure Live Lebanon project visibility

actual.comment: • 15 projects benefiting over 43,514 direct beneficiaries and more than 120,000 indirect beneficiaries were implemented. The implemented projects fall under the four pillars of the project (Young Lebanon, Prosperous Lebanon, Green Lebanon, and Healthy Lebanon). • 10 events were conducted to ensure the visibility of the project activities and to raise funds. • Live Lebanon was able to renew the partnership with BBAC Bank, as well as to establish a new partnership with senteur d'orient.

target.comment: At least 15 community based projects are implemented At least 3 partnerships with private sector are developed At least two events are executed to ensure Live Lebanon project visibility

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Listing of programs/activities for which technical assistance/coordination in institutional development was provided Listing of organizational procedures and related laws and decrees reviewed Number of capacity building activities designed and/or implemented 4. Increase of EMIS’ systems and applications use for information-based decision making, both at MEHE and at the school-level Listing of infrastructure expanded, innovated, and at which units Number of processes automated and used per directorate Number of MEHE units and public schools having adopted programs/projects/initiatives of ICT in Education and/or Number of students impacted by these Programs’ framework are developed and followed up on Listing of monitoring and evaluation processes integrated within the institutional operations development Monitoring and Evaluation data is being used for sector policy and planning Listing of technical assistance provided for the ESDP monitoring and evaluation related activities including operation and procedures manuals

baseline.comment: Education Sector Development Plan approved MIS system is being implemented Education Development Plan approved

target.comment: 1. Technical assistance/ coordination in institutional development provided 2. Organizational procedures and legal changes (where needed) within the implementation of the ESDP prepared Capacity building programs designed and/or implemented 3. Capacity building programs designed and/or implemented 4. The development, deployment and improvement of the different systems/ applications of the Education Management Information System (EMIS) is supported. 5. The establishment of new infrastructure (hardware, networks, and communication platforms) and expansion of existing one, centrally at MEHE, in the regional offices, and in public schools is supported 6. Technical assistance for the development and follow up of programs’ framework provided 7. Monitoring and evaluation procedures within MEHE institutional operations activities integrated

actual.comment: 1. The Early Childhood Evaluation Scale (ECERS) tool adapted to the local context. 68 schools took part in the ECERS activity finalized. 2. ICT in Education Training provided with 20 schools in the pilot program. 3. School Information Management System (SIMS) project's primary outputs presented to the relevant stakeholders. 4. Network infrastructure and cabling within 6 REOs fully deployed. 5. Support provided to USAID funded D-RASATI program, to the European Union funded program on improving achievement and reducing retention and scool information management system in public schools. 6. MEHE assisted to utilize, monitor and analyze tools for assessing school readiness.

target.comment: 1. The automation of the administration processes centrally at MEHE, in the regional offices, and in public schools is supported. 2. The Information, Communication, and Telecommunication (ICT) in Education initiatives is supported. 3. The delivery of required data outputs from the EMIS is supported. 4. Technical assistance for the ESDP monitoring and evaluation related activities is supported. 5. The formulation of operation and procedures manuals for monitoring and evaluation is supported.

actual.comment: 1. School connectivity: 20% of target met; planning to reach 60% by end of 2016. 2. The application for schools and MEHE's administration automation has been finalized; will be deployed in 2016. 3. 30% of departments have gone through institutional reform and implemented the development plan. 4. 70% of private school's automation completed.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Number of SMEs financed - Number of new jobs created in under-served regions - Number of SMEs received business support for financial inclusion - Number of individuals benefited from project interventions - Number of community development projects implemented

baseline.comment: - SMEs have limited access to credits in under-served regions of Lebanon - SMEs have limited access to business support in under-served regions of Lebanon - Local development initiatives scattered and implemented with limited impact

target.comment: Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon

actual.comment: • 107 credit applications for projects’ financing were submitted by the BDS officers to ESFD partner banks. • 79 projects directed through BDS officers were financed, accounting for almost 44% of total projects financed by the 5 partner banks. • A total of 181 projects (loans amounting to LBP 4.4 million) were financed in the targeted regions to increase the growth and prosperity for small and medium enterprises in the under-served regions of Lebanon. These projects are expected to create 166 jobs. • Rapid needs assessments were conducted in the communities that are hosting Syrian Refugees in the North and Bekaa. • Priority projects were identified in these areas.

target.comment: Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: • Investment promotion strategy developed • KPIs for monitoring implementation of investment promotion strategy & communication strategy set • Modus operandi of foreign investors advisory committee developed • Policy proposal on IDAL’s role in economic zones developed • Action plan on investors satisfaction with investment climate developed • Export Plus policy proposal developed • Communication strategy developed • 3-year strategic plan developed • Annual action plans developed • MoUs signed • Database of economic, commercial & legal indicators developed and updated • SWOT of economic sectors developed • Public-private committees held and sector recommendations developed • Database of investment opportunities developed • New website structure developed • Plan for targeting expatriates developed and database of target investors developed • Promotional materials developed • Applications for evaluating project proposals developed • Investors toolkit developed • MoUs with ministries signed • Aftercare program developed • Survey questionnaire developed and commissioned to external entities

baseline.comment: Lack of a clear investment promotion strategy for Lebanon and capacities to implement such a strategy. Limited capacities to conduct monitoring & evaluation functions. Limited data on investment related indicators and knowledge sharing tools.

target.comment: 1. Assessment of Law 360 achievements conducted. 2. FDI figures by sector for 2013 and 2014 released. 3. IDAL's new website continuously updated. 4. At least one policy paper published 5. Media in local and regional markets campaigns implemented 6. Investment opportunities promoted. 7. More than 10 investment projects processed by year 8. Annual strategic action plans approved 9. Annual action plans approved 10. One foreign investor's workshop held annualy

actual.comment: 1. Developed a socio-economic impact assessment of IDAL’s incentives from 2004 till present 2. Conducted a survey on the usefulness of the ICT bids services for Lebanon 3. Compiled information on foreign investments in Lebanon in 2014 4. Drafted an Investment Climate Assessment report for 2014 and an Investment Outlook for 2015 5. Supported IDAL in developing and disseminating 3 investment promotional newsletters 6. Published a study on investment opportunities in 3 Lebanese regions 7. Analyzed the business plan of 4 investment projects 8. Developed the annual and quarterly reports for the Agri Plus program 9. Drafted the 2015 Action Plan for the Agri Plus program

target.comment: 1. Develop a program to support the media sector 2. At least 60% of the strategies to promote export of agricultural goods implemented 3. IDAL's outreach to new and existing investors increased by at least 50% 4. Implement at least one initiative related to attracting diaspora investments to Lebanon

actual.comment: 1. Support provided to the media sector resulting in development of knowledge tools incl. a white paper to identify means to finance the movie industry, capacity development of key stakeholders, and the signature of an MOU with Fondation Liban Cinema to encourage investments in the media sector 2. The 60% target reached through the introduction of a new program to mitigate the Syrian crisis impact on Lebanese exports 3. Outreach to more than 50% of new investors through investor targeting conferences, aggressive media campaign (increase of 70% of social media community), and sector specific fact sheets 4. Partnership developed with the MIEUX program (EU initiative) facilitated by a mapping exercise resulting in the development of a strategy

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -- Economic growth strategy developed - Economic forecast models developed - Stakeholders coordination implemented - Sectoral studies and newsletters published and disseminated - Sectoral policies developed - Number of legislations drafted, amended and submitted to the Council of Ministers - Number of reformed procedures introduced in the Ministry - IT needs assessed and strategy developed and implemented - Support to SMEs provided and capacities enhanced - Transfer of technical and human resources to administration achieved

baseline.comment: -There is a need to develop and implement well-founded trade and economic policies, and to improve the business environment as well as to strengthen the commercial legal framework aimed at encouraging investment -Despite support provided in the first phase of the project, the capacities of the Ministry’s IT structure, SMEs support, trade activities, and implementation of high impact projects, are limited and still need improvements until full functional integration to the administration.

target.comment: 1. Existing trade agreements (EU, GAFTA, EFTA, bilateral) assessed. 2. SMEs capacity supported 3. Inter- operability with relevant third parties insured 4. Procedures needing reforms identified. 5. Economic Forecast models and analysis tools developed 6. Information and knowledge disseminated 7. Trade in Services sectors analysis and statistical data base enhanced

actual.comment: 1. Assessment of Lebanon’s Free Trade Agreements 2. Developed and published the “Lebanon SME strategy: a Roadmap to 2020” 3. Coordination and implementation of the EU- Lebanon action plan, EU Rules of Origin Convention, Safeguard measures (Vegetable oil, Scrap, Olive oil and Steel), laws and regulations 4. Liaised with the Prime Minister’s office and Council of Development and Reconstruction on setting up a Donor’s Coordination mechanism. 5. Research and Analysis provided through the development of trade partners countries profiles and Updating Economic Database on a Weekly and monthly Basis 6. - The International Awareness campaign on the challenges and needs facing the Lebanese Hosting Communities from the Syrian refugee influx Launched at the Grand Serail - Continued training and Capacity building activities and workshops : WTO issues, Rules of Origin by sectors 7. Continued the preparations related to TIFM : Trade and Investment Facilitation Mechanism (EU regional project)

target.comment: 1. Prospective trade agreements negotiations evaluated and supported ( WTO, AGADIR, MERCOSUR, ...) 2. Sectoral studies , especially in services sectors developed 3. Support SMEs development in Lebanon 4. Legal amendment and additions introduced (ongoing) 5. MoET e-services supported

actual.comment: 1. Established a WTO Reference Center for Lebanon at the MOET. Provided legal evaluations and suggested legal decrees and bi/multilateral agreements in the framework of the GAFTA and WTO. Launched the MERCOSUR Lebanon Free Trade agreement consultations. 2. Developed a study on the Technology and Innovation Ecosystem in Lebanon. Reviewed KPIs for SMEs in Lebanon. 3. Surveying more than 700 SMEs to consolidate opportunities for entrepreneurs. 4. Approval of 7 laws by parliament (ref. Official Gazette No. 48) drafted/supported by the project on money laundering, food safety, economic cooperation agreements (China, etc), and anti-corruption. 5. Automated a number of e-services in the intellectual property and consumer protection departments.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Internship program established - Training provided to Parliamentary Administration employees - Support provided to Parliament to address reform issues with key stakeholders/participatory approach - Inter-parliamentary agreements reached - Accountability role of parliamentarians exercised and issues raised - Information disclosed - Tracking system for legislative process developed - Media Campaign to promote Human Rights Action Plan developed - Support provided to the Human Right Parliamentary Committee - National Human Rights Action Plan finalized and adopted

baseline.comment: Need to modernize the current organizational and administrative structure of the parliament, and to develop capacities of and provide support to the administration to address critical reform issues Need for further follow-up on Parliamentary Interrogations, and enhancing the understanding of government accountability to the Parliament Need to implement and follow-up on the National Human Rights Action Plan and mainstreaming Human Rights in Parliamentary work.

target.comment: 1. Lebanese Parliamentary Internship Program (LPIP) implemented 2. Establishing an E-Library database on experts and studies and classifying them according to thematic areas

actual.comment: 1. The LPIP database currently contains more than 200 applications of candidates from different academic backgrounds. More than 30 interns have completed internships with different parliamentary committees including Public Works, Transportation, Energy and Water, and the Administration and Justice. 2. - The electronic database has been developed and available to MPs and parliamentary administration when needed. - Assistance provided to the UNDP consultant at the Office of the Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs (OMSPA) project and UNDP at the Office of the Minister of State for Administrative reform (OMSAR) to develop an online tracking legislative system.

target.comment: 1. Organizing at least 2 training sessions for CSOs on women quota with the participation of relevant committees. 2. Organizing an event on the International Human Rights Day to launch the final NHRIP 3. Enrolling at least 5 new interns through the Lebanese Parliamentary Internship Program (LPIP) 4. Partnerships developed with Parliamentary Committees

actual.comment: 1. Co-organized a national conference on special temporary measures for women participation in elections, with CSOs, women candidates, and representatives of major political blocks (Member of Parliaments) . Participated in the sessions of the Administration and Justice Parliamentary Committee to suggest the introduction of a 30% women quota to the electoral law (as a starting point). Received commitment from a number of Members of Parliament incl. the Speaker of Parliament on the adoption of the quota. Published a Q&A guide on the women quota and a study on the role of women in political parties. 2. Launched (in partnership with the Arab NGO Network for Development) the 2015 Universal Periodic Review on Human Rights report. Awareness was raised among CSOs, Members of Parliament, and experts, with recommendations and mechanisms to implement the recommendations. A task force was accordingly established. 3. 9 new interns joined the LPIP and worked with committees, directorates, and parliamentary administration. 4. Active partnerships in the form of support (logistical and advisory) provided to the Administration and Justice, Human Rights, Youth, and Woman and Child Parliamentary Committees.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1-Data on living condition and needs in Palestinian gatherings (including Adjacent Areas) produced. 1.2-3Ws (who's doing what where) matrix developed and populated by NGOs 1.3-GIS national base map linked to collected data in the gatherings developed and shared. 1.4-Number of reports published 1.5-Number of policy papers developed and discussed with relevant central government agencies. 1.6-Number of consultative sessions held with Lebanese and Palestinian stakeholders to discuss proposed policy options 2.1-Analysis of existing collaborative mechanisms between Palestinians and Lebanese produced 2.2-Collaborative mechanisms established. 2.3-Number of joint initiatives implemented 2.4-Action plans to initiate and/or sustain collaborative mechanisms developed 2.5-Number of joint sessions held gathering concerned local stakeholders, and national authorities (including the LPDC). 2.6-Best practices documented and disseminated at the national level. 3.1-Number of community Improvement Plans of living conditions in the Adjacent Areas developed 3.2-Number of upgrading and infrastructure projects completed in selected Adjacent Areas 3.3.1-Community based plans for operating and maintaining basic urban services developed and in use by the local communities. 3.3.2-Decreasing use of adhoc methods to access basic urban services by the communities 4.1-Platform bringing together various municipalities created for experience sharing and outreach 4.2-Number of coordination meetings facilitated

baseline.comment: 1-Lack of data and of achievable policy options for Palestinian Gatherings living conditions 2-Absence of collaborative mechanisms for improved service delivery. 3-Inadequate living environment and basic urban services in Adjacent Areas 4-Limited municipal capacity, resources and know-how to respond to the issues faced by the Adjacent Areas.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Improvement in key fiscal indicators Reports (statistics) on public services, social programs and subsides, and beneficiaries published MTEF updates completed Deviation of publications calendar controlled client/user satisfaction and action (survey) provided The publication of the debt management strategy The extent of deviation from the financing target FX and LL bond issuance successfully undertaken Number of tax conventions and investment agreements signed and results Proportion of legal reviews and advisory notes accepted/acted upon Report on reform implementation TA implementation ratio against plan TA evaluation and beneficiaries survey Budget support disbursed Grants and loans mobilized as forecasted Sector financing plans approved Aid effectiveness measures adopted Higher compliance rate Improved services Increased revenues collection Reduction in clearance time Reduction on clearance cost Stabilization of effective tariff rate Increase in voluntary compliance Inter-governmental collaboration Compliance with international obligations

baseline.comment: The fiscal situation at the end of 2010 shows gaps in the macro-fiscal policy measures, gauged by the main fiscal indicators and by public services, social programs, subsidies, and beneficiaries as in 2010. The 2010 MTEF. The publications programme as achieved in 2010. 2010 Medium-term debt management strategy (internal dissemination). The 2010 Financing plan. The results of the 64 tax agreements and 49 investment agreements reached in 2010 and on the legal reviews and advisory notes completed in 2010. Building on the reform programmes implemented in the previous years and responding to the gaps that remain to be filled: The Paris III MoF reform programme implementation as of end 2010. TA data base and neeeds as of end 2010. Annual aid mobilization forecast as achieved end 2010. Project-based financing situation as of end 2010. Progress of tax reform programme implementation as of end 2010 Weaknesses in the current facilitations and compliance as follows: Clearance of cargo: Average 5 days or above Documentation:Average 10 docs per transaction Compliant self assessment: Red lane 30 percent Satisfaction level of trade community: Medium to Low Percent added revenue due to Enforcement: Less than 2 percent Percent Non-compliant operations: Estimated 10-15 percent

target.comment: 1. Impact of the Syrian conflict on the revenues and expenditures, including EDL and interest payments thoroughly studied 2. Annual financing targets met 3. Upgraded and a more flexible debt simulation tool developed incorporating new financing developments in terms of debt holders and instruments to provide short to medium-term projections of financing and debt aggregates 4. At least five investment agreements negotiated 5. Fiscal reform programme implementation monitored and reported on IFIs, EIB relationship managed and portfolio developed 6. Large Taxpayers Office merger implemented 7. Awareness and communication campaigns launched. 8. Customs reform programme initiatives implemented

actual.comment: 1. Actively kept track of the Syrian displaced impact and the various new salary scale scenarios and incorporated them into the fiscal and debt scenarios based on latest available draft laws. 2. Updated funding plan for 2015 and provided advisory services to Minister of Finance on foreign currency issuance schedule. Subjected the debt simulation model to a number of updates and elaborated a more flexible financing strategy. 3. Constructed a new five-year forward looking model that allows assessment of foreign currency debt dynamics under baseline projections and incorporating alternative scenarios and stress tests. 4. Followed up on the World Bank Grant for Lebanon "PCB Management in the Power Sector Project" 5. The 2015 Tax Calendar was prepared, issued and distributed 6. In partnership with OMT, an awareness campaign regarding the BPT and related services (including payment through OMT) was launched in November. 7. Paperless implementation in all the Customs offices.

target.comment: 1. Incentive proposals for sustainable energy submitted 2. Growth model for MoF implemented 3. Model developed to study the impact of oil discoveries on fiscal and debt 4. Second phase of transfer to administration completed 5. Thematic report series developed and reports widely disseminated 6. Sustainable energy/environment portfolio institutionalized 7. Requests for legal review and advice satisfactorily met/acted upon 8. Aid mobilization annual target achieved 9. Large Taxpayers Office merger procedures implemented 10. Performance Management System implemented 11. Operational Call Centre ensured 12. E-services business rules provided 13. Awareness and communication campaigns launched 15. New GIS solution implemented

actual.comment: 1. Developed a medium term macro-fiscal framework for 2015 onwards. 2. Managed the highest Eurobond transaction ever accomplished amounting to 2.8 BN US Dollars. 3. Created a five-year debt model to assess financial and debt risks. 4. Provided suggestions to the amendment of the money laundering law passed by Parliament (ref. Official Gazette no. 48). 5. Introduced at least 10 new forms to facilitate tax procedures and services. Established new automated modules for the Tax administration. Launched an e-services platform to speed up processes and transactions for citizens. Established a one stop shop for 128 transactions. Call center strategy developed. 6. Modernization of the Land Registry and Cadastre administration supported by automation based on international best practices and training of all staff on new systems. Opening of new regional centers in South Lebanon to decentralize processes.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: •No of services delivered •No of participatory plans •No. of scholarships for school •No. of patients assisted •All municipalities have coordination mechanisms •Number of community committees formed. •Number of participants in the community committees. •Number of assessments completed in a participatory manner. •Number of individuals trained on dispute resolution. •Percentage of trained individuals actively solving disputes in their communities. •Number of assessments and updates undertaken. •Number of assessments provided to the government. •Number of coordination meetings held.

baseline.comment: •High unemployment amongst youth and women; •Limited job opportunities and weak private sector investment; •Loss and/or depletion of livelihood assets, and economic opportunities •Weak economic and productive infrastructures; •Limited financial services targeting poor and vulnerable people. •Limited knowledge on the available services by the local communities is contributing to the increasing tension. •Lack of services •Vulnerable population unable to access services •Lack of participatory mechanisms for service delivery •Local communities are vulnerable to external shocks due to limited skills and institutionalized mechanisms for preventing tension from exploding into conflict. •Lack of institutionalized local level mechanisms for dealing with disputes. •Lack of systematic conflict prevention and conflict resolution instruments being utilized by local leaders. •Limited skill base of key local leaders in dealing with disputes and conflicts affecting their villages.

target.comment: ▪ At least 100 Inter-Sectorial Municipal Action Plans developed ▪ At least 55 host communities targeted ▪ At least 150 projects implemented across different sectors

actual.comment: • A total of 145 communities were mapped and the respective Inter-Sectorial Municipal Action Plans were developed. • The capacity of local actors was strengthened in the delivery of basic services in a participatory manner. In addition, the ability and space for the local government and the civil society to interact was built to ensure that information is exchanged and that priorities are jointly identified. • A total of 173 projects were implemented targeting 60 municipalities and 6 Union of municipalities, aiming at improving livelihoods, strengthening the basic services sector for better service delivery and supporting the education and health sector. • The projects benefitted 644,736 Lebanese and 179,627 displaced Syrians.

target.comment: ▪ At least 50 Inter-Sectorial Municipal Action Plans developed ▪ At least 60 host communities targeted ▪ At least 170 projects implemented across different sectors

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Number and type of advisory roles on electoral reform Number and type of reports/manuals/videos/plans produced and/or published/broadcast Number of trainers trained Number and type of election officials trained Number of election districts using new results process. Number of citizens reached by voter information Number of users accessing on-line voter register Number of media briefings at media centre In case ballots are adopted, number of invalid ballot Number of new vote secrecy processes adopted in law. In case ballots are adopted, number of ballots produced. In case absentee voting is adopted, number of voters who participate as absentee voters Number of election districts included in data-management system Number of measures to improve accessibility adopted Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders Number and type of advisory role on campaign supervision Number and type of documents/reports/manuals produced Number and type of regulatory and procedural improvements in place Number of SCEC members and staff trained Number of participants in workshops/consultative meetings Number and type of official information on campaign supervision released Number of users of web content on campaign supervision Number of observers/media accredited Number of reports produced Number of stakeholder participants trained Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders Number of initiatives supported Number of reports produced Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders Number of judges/members, experts and stakeholders participating in events Number and type of advisory roles on Temporary Special Measures (TSMs) In case TSMs are adopted, number of stakeholders trained Number of women recruited as election officials Number of reports produced Number of consultative workshops with stakeholders

baseline.comment: Political debate on electoral reform on-going Limited technical capacity for advising on reform initiatives Inadequate technical framework for results process Limited technical capacity for improving results framework Need to ensure accurate and reliable results process Limited experience and capacity for official voter information No current strategy for official role on voter information and media; increasing political role for social media Limited use and awareness of online voter register Broad public knowledge of importance of elections but limited knowledge of electoral issues Emerging role and expectation for official websites and voter information on citizens’ rights Limited official resources for meeting media interest Possible political consensus on measures for vote secrecy No current capacity for ballot production and limited technical knowledge on options for counting and absentee voting No strategic capacity for training of officials in place All polling officials require updated training, especially if new electoral procedures to be adopted Limited technical capacity and resources for operational planning and data-management Limited opportunities for Persons With Disabilities (PWD) to access electoral process Debate for future reform of legislative and administrative framework for elections is likely to intensify Donors of electoral assistance will seek quality assurance. Next elections will take place in 2016 and 2017 SCEC has no current functional capacity. SCEC members and staff will be new with limited elections experience Regulatory framework for campaign supervision identified as inadequate No strategy or capacity for stakeholder outreach in place Limited capacity for observer accreditation in place Significant interest from observer/media expected Debate for future strengthening of campaign supervision is expected to take place Donors of electoral assistance will seek quality assurance No baseline data or coordinat

target.comment: 1. Awareness and understanding of Electoral law options increased 2. Procedural basis for an improved results management framework has been developed. 3. Software tool for tabulating, aggregating and transferring election results developed 4. Registration of candidates improved process adopted. 5. Improved process for gathering polling station data has been adopted 6. MOIM engagement on external relations on elections has been facilitated 7. Effective public awareness campaigns on voter registration implemented 8. Different ballots for different electoral systems developed 9. Review of polling and counting processes conducted 10. Capacity of electoral officials has been improved through professional development 11. Capacity of electoral officials improved through peer-to-peer knowledge sharing 12. Capacity of the MOIM to deliver training improved 13. Capacity of the MOIM to prepare for election operations improved. 14. Awareness on voter education capacity needs is increased 15. Awareness and Understanding of issues related to Women’s Participation in Politics is increased

actual.comment: 1. Analysis and explanatory materials on all relevant electoral system options being considered by Parliament during 2013 and 2014, including translation of the draft laws prepared. 2. Detailed analysis of relevant results management systems for Lebanon prepared and an improved structure proposed. comprehensive plan for the implementation of the proposed results management system, which was accepted as a basis by the MOIM adapted. 3. ‘Turnkey’ software tool, including processes for the real-time gathering and publication of results data developed 4. Standardized candidate registration forms that have been developed and adopted by the MOIM and used by all candidates. Ministry staff trained on using the process. 5. Project deployed a UN Volunteer to support the MOIM in data-entry of polling station data. 6. Draft strategies produced for MoIM, branding, activated social media, hotline, public documents, and media center established. 7. Conducted a draft comprehensive public survey to assess the success and impact of the public awareness campaigns. 8. Prototype ballots and different standardized ballots developed. 9. Developed a concept note for the establishment of ‘mega-poling centres’ that can accommodate large numbers of voters in a secured zone, including allowing voters to vote in a location outside of their assigned district. 10. Provided senior MOIM officials with targeted training on electoral systems, election management structures, candidate registration and results management processes, ballot papers, and changes to polling and counting processes, election operational planning and warehouse management, promoting women in electoral processes, and voter registration. Project has also provided MOIM officials with detailed briefings and advisory activity on an extensive range of electoral topics. 11. South-South Cooperation: Observation of the 2014 Indian parliamentary elections. 12. Developed a series of ‘Readiness Index’ to identify the steps that were require

target.comment: 1. Improved candidate registration system 2. Improved results management system 3. Enhanced electoral dispute resolution processes 4. Outreach material provided 5. Increased awareness on Temporary Special Measures for women participation

actual.comment: 1. CRRM software to modernize candidate registration and results management finalized, tested, and provided to the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities. System preliminary adopted by the Directorate General for Personal Status. 2. Developed partnership with the constitutional council, providing it with technical support to be able to address electoral disputes. Information capacity of the council enhanced with a website and the publication of 2 legal references (guidebook and compilation of decisions). The project received a recognition award for its contributions. 3. Capacities on elections operations strengthened through the publication of an electoral atlas for each electoral district with elections related data and improved storage capacity and management of electoral material through the establishment of an automated system. 4. Increased awareness on women participation provided with advisory support to parliamentary committees, with the provision of information and alternatives and facts, and co-organization of a national conference to discuss Temporary Special measures.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Saida dumpsite totally rehabilitated and environmental impacts mitigated.

baseline.comment: Current dumpsite presents high risk and environmental hazard, and absence of baseline data

target.comment: -Implementation of the Turnkey Contract for Rehabilitation of Saida Dumpsite: treatment and proper disposal of around 100% of the volume of waste (1.5 million cubic meters), three cells are constructed, design of public park and design of final cap including drainage system are finalized. -Local Communities are trained and their capacity is built ensuring their cooperation and involvement in the implementation.

actual.comment: -Implementation of the Turnkey Contract for Rehabilitation of Saida Dumpsite: • Treatment of 100% of the whole volume of wastes = the trash mountain is removed completely. • Construction of all three cells of the sanitary landfill and filling with organic wastes. • Installation of the leachate collection system. • Testing around 500 samples in the site laboratory. • Installation of the gas collection network and bio-filters. • Capping the landfill with geo-membrane liner and protecting it with fine material. • Finalizing design of the park: landscape, plantation, irrigation, drainage, etc. -Communication material including brochure and presentation for schools (targeting secondary level students), local NGOs, etc. delivered.

target.comment: -The rehabilitated dumpsite is converted into two sections: 1) a Public Park (area 33,500 sqm) including 10,452 trees and plants and irrigation system open to citizens; and b) a sanitary engineered landfill becomes a green hill 65,000 sqm. All infrastructure (fences, access road, drainage, guard house/equipped room) is completed; gas and leachate are monitored.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Number of NSDS launched and adopted by MoSA - Elaboration and adaptation of National Social Development Plan - Issuance of a contractual modality with clear standards between MoSA and NGOs. - Number of NGOs classified according to an accreditation system - Number of welfare institutions classified according to an accreditation system. - Percentage of low qualified contacted NGO’s & welfare institutions trained. - Percentage of MoSA staff trained. - Establishment of an active & solid networking between MOSA, NGOs and other donors.

baseline.comment: - Lack of a national social development strategy to be adopted by ministers, NGOs, local authorities for implementing local initiatives and promoting sustainable development. - Lack of training tools and techniques to build the capacities of MoSA staff. - Absence of clear standards for selecting qualified NGOs for contractual cooperation with MoSA. - Lack of a solid networking mechanism to formulate the cooperation between MoSA and NGOs, among NGOs themselves and between NGOs and other donors. - Lack of a coherant platform among MoSA, NGOs and other donors for sharing data and and information available on services and beneficiaries in an attempt to avoid duplication and to ensure a sound allocation of resources.

target.comment: Re-launch the National Social Development Strategy of Lebanon

actual.comment: • Extensive meetings conducted with the different departments at the Ministry of Social Affairs to assess the training centers and to re-launch the National Social Development Strategy.

target.comment: The National Social Development Strategy is launched and adopted by MoSA An action plan is elaborated New criteria & contractual procedure are established

indicator.description: -Amount of reduced CO2 emissions by the investments facilitated by the project -Volume of investments mobilized -Extent to which RE policies and regulations are adopted and enforced -Availability of annual market data; Verified customer satisfaction with the RE technologies in use

baseline.comment: -0 reduction of CO2 emissions -Regulations for feed-in tariffs and net metering under consideration -No adequate market monitoring and quality control mechanisms in place

target.comment: Project team is established at the Ministry of Energy and Water

actual.comment: -Project Team is established and the Project is initiated by drafting the inception report, the annual work plans, and budget and preparing for the inception workshop.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Reducing greenhouse gas emissions by the removal of barriers to widespread application of decentralized renewable energy based power generation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Amount of reduced CO2 emissions by the investments facilitated by the project

target.comment: Direct: 35,500 tonnes of CO2eq over the 20-year default lifetime of the investments made during project implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Cumulative renewable energy capacity installed and operational (MWp)

target.comment: 1.75 MWp

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Cumulative renewable energy generation (MWh/year)

target.comment: 3,285 MWh/year

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Investments in decentralized renewable energy (RE) power generation increased

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Volume of investments mobilized

target.comment: US$ 8.75 million

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: An enforced supportive policy and regulatory environment for attracting investments for privately owned, grid-connected power generation by RE sources

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent to which RE policies and regulations are adopted and enforced

baseline.comment: Regulations for feed-in tariffs and net metering under consideration

target.comment:
Net metering effectively implemented and complemented with other required regulations and/or guidance, including updated technical guidelines for grid connection as well as adopted standards and procedures for performance testing and quality control.
Mechanism and guidelines for the implementation of feed-in-tariffs developed.

actual.comment:
Net-metering program launched but currently postponed as it is facing technical difficulties.
Feed-in-Tariff program under consideration.
Renewable energy grid code study being launched.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Monitoring and quality control for RE-based decentralized power generation established and operational

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Availability of annual market data;
Verified customer satisfaction with the RE technologies in use

baseline.comment: No adequate market monitoring and quality control mechanisms in place

target.comment:
Availability of annual market data for new sales, total installed capacity and net production of all main RE applications sold in Lebanon by March/April each year.
Over 70% customers satisfaction on the RE installations made

actual.comment:
No adequate market monitoring. DREG is working on the development of a market monitoring scheme.
Quality control mechanisms being developed with responsible national agencies (LIBNOR and IRI).

indicator.description: A wholesale vegetable and fruit farmers’ market established in Nabatieh. Number of farmers benefiting from the market. Number of farmers accessing the Extension services. At least 4 thematic and technical trainings conducted.

baseline.comment: No agricultural public market exits in the region.

target.comment: A farmers’ market in Nabatieh city is established Access to agricultural extension services is improved

actual.comment: • The latest results achieved on the construction site were the following: foundation finished and steel columns erected in Block B. In Block C the construction of the second floor was completed and inside works started. In Block D, the construction of the first floor was finalized. MEAMAR started the construction of the second floor. • The list of needed equipment was prepared and procurement will start in 2015. • To ensure the improvement of the agricultural extension services, UNDP project team was working closely with the Ministry of Agriculture and the Municipality of Nabatieh to schedule the training to farmers as well as procuring the needed equipment. In this respect: 1. The Ministry of Agriculture representatives prepared the agenda for the training of the farmers and the cooperatives. 2. The Map of the cooling room was submitted to the Ministry of Agriculture in order to start the procurement process. 3. The management board meeting as agreed with municipality of Nabateih and Ministry of agriculture will take place in the first quarter of 2015.

target.comment: A farmers’ market in Nabatieh city is established Access to agricultural extension services is improved

location.name: Lebanon
location.activity-description: Palestian Refugees living in 42 Palestinian Gatherings all over Lebanon

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -1. Number of Infrastructure and BUS interventions executed in gatherings -2. Number of hygiene awareness raising campaigns carried out in Palestinian gatherings -3. Local authorities and local committees in the gathering supported to set-up collaborative mechanisms for improved service delivery -4. Number of municipalities engaged for improving living conditions in Palestinian gatherings -5. Number of refugee households benefitting from shelter rehabilitation and internal works -6. Number of MOUs signed between Municipalities and Popular Committees -7. Number of Hygiene kits distributed -8. National Observatory for Palestinian Gatherings in Lebanon supported for data generation / dissemination and planning tool -9. Indicators for monitoring living conditions in Palestinian gatherings developed and updated -10. A structure to host and disseminate geographic database of Palestinian gatherings in Lebanon is set-up -11. National actors and organizations active in the gatherings use data to plan and coordinate their interventions

baseline.comment: •Number of dwellers in the Gatherings has risen 47%, in the last assessment conducted by Habitat and UNDP, as a result of the Syrian crisis. •Inadequate access to basic urban services for some 75,000 original dwellers in Palestinian gatherings. •Increased pressure on basic urban services and infrastructure networks in the gatherings by 35,000 newly arrived Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria • Lack of institutions / agencies responsible for the provision of basic urban services in the gatherings •Limited Municipal engagement to improve living environment and infrastructure networks in Palestinian gatherings • Limited capacities, resources and know-how of local actors and authorities to respond to the issues in the Palestinian gatherings. • Lack of communication and collaboration among local authorities and representatives of local communities in the gatherings for addressing local challenges • Additional 35,000 Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria are accommodated in Palestinian gatherings • Large numbers of displaced families were housed in temporary structures or units that are not equipped for accommodation • Shelter units housing Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria in the gatherings are inadequate • Large numbers of shelters housing Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria in the gatherings are not properly connected to infrastructure networks (water, sewage, electricity) • Lack of financial resources of host communities and refugees from Syria to improve environmental conditions of shelters • Lack of national-wide data for monitoring living conditions in Palestinian gatherings in Lebanon • Lack of accurate information on numbers and situation of arrived Palestinian and Syrian refugees from Syria to the gatherings • Lack of responsive strategy for improving living conditions in Palestinian gatherings in Lebanon based on accurate data and information • Need for enhanced coordination among key national actors and organizations

target.comment: -1. 32 -2. 12 -3. Capacities of key actors built -4. 3 -5. 600 -6. 1 -7. 4000 -8. Observatory completed -9. Indicated produced -10. Structure initiated -11. Data generated

actual.comment: -1. 32 -2. 12 -3. Capacities of key actors built through Joint meetings conducted between municipalities and Popular and Local Committees in areas of implementation -4. 3 -5. 575 -6. 1 -7. 3,800 -8. Observatory on hold -9. Indicated produced -10. Structure in progress -11. Data generated and used by actors in the Gatherings

target.comment: -1. 74 -2. 42 -3. Local authorities and committees further assisted -4. 5 -5. 2000 -6. 2 -7. 16350 -8. Observatory completed -9. Indicators revised -10. Structure setup -11. Additional data on gatherings generated

location.name: Wadi Khalid
location.activity-description: Rehabilitation of Water Network in Wadi Khaled

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Increased supply/storage of water to host communities in Wadi Khaled

baseline.comment: Limited supply and storage capacity available resulting in non-continuous supply of water

target.comment: -Needs assessment and design of water distribution network completed -ITB for the implementation is launched

actual.comment: -The design of water distribution network in one village (Hnaider), is completed in line with the needs assessment of the area. -Mobilised additional 2.1 million USD to cover additional villages in Wadi Khaled (North Lebanon). -Final designs completed for the additional villages, cleared by the North Lebanon Water Establishment and related procurement for the implementation is initaited.

target.comment: The construction of transmission and distribution water networks for Hnaider, Qarha & Knaise villages in Wadi Khaled, North Lebanon is 80 percent completed.

actual.comment: The network designs were cleared by the national authority in this regard which is the North Lebanese Water Establishment. 80 percent of the works is completed in close coordination with the hosting municipalities to ensure sustainability of the action.

location.name: Lebanon
location.activity-description: Beneficiaries of the Project are spread all over Lebanon, mainly in regions most affected by the Syrian Crisis

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Number of educators teaching Lebanese and Syrian students trained 2) Number of newsletters produced 3) Number of Peace building News Supplements published 4) Number of initiatives implemented to support collective memory through non-formal education channels. 5) Number of schools adopting the violence free schools principles 6) Number of history teachers trained on teaching sensitive topics 7) Number of reports produced on the implementation of the Journalists’ Pact 8) Number of media outlets cooperating to produce supplements 9) Number of regions targeted by local level interventions 10) Local level peace building strategies and mechanisms implemented in at least three conflict-prone areas 11) Number of local leaders trained on mediation, conflict resolution and crisis management 12) Awareness raised among the population about truth, reconciliation and dealing with the past 13) Ex-fighters supported to play a positive role and convey messages of peace 14) Consultations held with different segments of the Lebanese society 15) Number of conflict assessments and maps produced

baseline.comment: 1) Rising tensions in schools hosting Syrian refugees 2) Absence of a collective memory of the civil war 3) High level of violence in Lebanese public and private schools 4) Absence of context-specific peace education content in the current high school curricula (including civics/history/geography education 5) Limited opportunities within the formal education sector to build a collective memory 6) Absence of new and modern ways of teaching history and sensitive topics 7) Need to implement master training for teacher trainers in use of Peace Building Toolbox 8) Limited initiatives involving young generation in oral history and the need to work on historical narrative 9)Lack of impartial and multifaceted reporting on issues affecting social cohesion in Lebanon and with communities hosting Syrian refugees in particular 10)The Journalists’ Pact for Strengthening Civil Peace signed but not yet implemented 11)Limited media monitoring on the type of and effects of reporting 12)Poor or biased coverage of strategic issues regarding the implementation of past agreements 13)Lack of channels for conveying positive messages through media 14) Absence of sustained peace building and dialogue mechanisms to mitigate the risks of potential violence at the local level 15) Limited awareness of the role that local actors such as municipalities and mukhtars can play in conflict prevention and mitigation. 16) Worsening tension between the Lebanese host communities and the Syrian refugees 17) Lack of a joint road map and a national strategy for truth and reconciliation 18) Limited field research on the perception of the causes, lived experience, and impact of the civil war in Lebanon, 19) Lack of consultation and coordination with state, non-state and other various segments of the Lebanese society on reconciliation 20) Absence awareness among the population about truth, reconciliation and dealing with the past through media 21) Absence of active ex-fighters wanting to promote pe

target.comment: 2015 Target 1) 400 2) 4 3) 5 4) 2 5) 10 6) 30 7) 4 8) 2 9) 3 10) 3 11) 50 12) Awareness raised through sessions organized by ex-fighters, theatrical plays, and commemoration of the civil war 13) Ex-fighters support initiated 14) Extensive Consultations held 15) 2

actual.comment: 1) 350 2) 4 3) 4 4) 0 5) 10 6) 0 7) 2 8) 3 9) 3 10) Completed for 3 areas 11) 50 12) Work with ex-fighters initiated 13) Support initiated 14) NGOs platform assisted in organizing a series of consultation with political parties, syndicates and workers unions, families affected by the civil war, professional unions and associations, cooperatives, bankers, youth both employed and unemployed, and ex-fighters but not completed and process support ensured for the national civil society platform 15) 2

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Potential beneficiary institutions identified and categorized, on a continuous basis, by sector and very brief profile produced on each. - Available TOKTEN skills identified and categorized on a continuous basis. TOKTEN missions arranged on an annual basis - TOKTEN missions monitored and evaluated. - Outreach and communication activities implemented. - Regularly updated and easily accessible and well-advertised website.

baseline.comment: - 6 to 7 missions accomplished every year since the beginning of the project - Outreach is limited to one brochure and regular broadcast emails

target.comment: 1. 6 to 7 missions implemented.

actual.comment: 1. A total of 10 TOKTEN missions were implemented in support of the Prime Minister's Office, 4 ministries and 2 institutions: - Mission with Ministry of Interior's ISF Cybercrime Bureau on optimizing cybercrime fighting. - Mission with the Lebanese Armed Forces on cyber defense and building blocks and challenges Seminar - Mission with Lebanese Armed Forces on “Petroleum Resources in the East Mediterranean “ Seminar - Mission with Lebanese Armed Forces titled "Towards a Secure Cyberspace Review" - Mission with the Office of the Minister for Administrative Reform (OMSAR) on Change Management Training - Mission with the Ministry of Interior to ISF Financial Crimes Bureau on Improving Detection of Fraudulent bankruptcies - Mission with the Ministry of Health on the ongoing Progress in the National Orthopedic Implants Guidelines - Mission with the Ministry of Industry about ongoing Food safety Guidelines in Agro-food industries. - Mission with Parliament: On Going Food safety Law - Mission to Prime Minister's Office and ICT On-going sector support

target.comment: 1. At least 7 missions conducted 2. At least 5 beneficiary institutions identified and targeted 3. New partnerships developed

actual.comment: 1. A total of 9 missions were conducted in 2015, including the development of food safety guidelines, capacity building initiatives on road safety, change management trainings for public officials, and fiscal and cybercrime awareness. 2. Capacity development targeted 7 beneficiary instutions, including ones that were not targeted before such as the Internal Security Forces. 130 public officials benefited from capacity building initiatives, among which 40% were women. 3. Two new partnerships were developed with the Institute of Finance and the Central Bank, the results of which will be reflected in the new phase.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Restructuring plans developed - Coordination initiatives enhanced -Launch specific social and economic projects including support to entrepreneurs - E-government platform and tools developed - Regular ICT Ministerial Committee meetings held at least quarterly - Number of developed ICT policies and regulations - Internal and external communication strategies developed and tested - Number of publications drafted and disseminated - Number of infrastructural projects developed and implemented

baseline.comment: Need for more thorough coordination among institutions on policies The national e-strategy plan is developed but needs implementation and follow-up Successful implementation of infrastructural projects, that need to be enhanced and further elaborated

target.comment: 1. Reform of the statistical system in Lebanon 2. Improving the business environment in Lebanon 3. National Poverty Targeting Program supported 4. Cultural and Religious Tourism plan resumed 5. e-strategy plan followed-up

actual.comment: 1. Amendments suggested to reform the central administration of statistics, maintaining its independence from political interventions and strengthening its authority. 2. Supported the central bank in developing a circular to settle debt resolution cases of companies, a draft law on preferred shares submitted to parliament. 3. Funds were secured to provide e-card voucher for 5,027 deprived households. More funds were mobilized to increase target in 2016 (aiming at 27,000 households). 4. Resumed the Cultural and Religious Tourism project. Discussions launched with municipalities and religious groups. 5. Coordinating e-strategy/ICT work with ministries to generate new ICT policies, all finalized and submitted to the Council of Ministers. Finalize equipment of 5 regional operations rooms on disaster risk management. Kick started phase 1 of the automation process of the Office of the Presidency of the Council of Ministers.
